archetypes.title: Cycling
description: This is the cycling deck; red and white have really good cycling pay-offs. A perfect example is Savai Thundermane, dealing 2 damage to target creature and gaining 2 life is icing on the cake when I'm trying to cycle through unwanted spells.

Cycling remains a strong mechanic as it allows a higher density of threats and more consistency in your deck. Considering this you may even want to adjust your typical land-to-spell ratio so you don't run into too many lands while cycling.

archetypes.title: Flyers
description: This is your typical flyer deck, blockers on the bottom and flyers up top. This archetype has the most access to flying creature with 13 of the 18 flyers in the whole set being playable in blue white.
You are going to want to back up those flyers with proper counters and removal. Blue-White has great access to common level removal and counters such as Pacifism, Capture Sphere, and Essence Scatter.

archetypes.title: Mutate
description: Mutating seems gross I know, and sometimes it will be if you mutate a creature only to have it die to a single removal spell. The trick in this archetype will be determining when we have mutated too far and start to think "should I" instead of "can I".

This mechanic is posed to be successful in limited. We want to be playing large threats and mutating our smaller creatures in this deck. I can see runaway games happening in this archetype from early mutations that don't get answered by the opponent. It's important to also be wary when mutating a creature; you may be making a valuable target for a removal spell your opponent has been sitting on.

archetypes.title: Graveyard
description: Black-Green is back from the dead with lots of graveyard interactions. The goal here is to play big threats and have removal in case your favorite mutant dies. The pain will be eased in knowing you can bring them back with cards like Back for More.

If you have the chance to pull some cycling cards in your deck there will be some interesting interactions. Imagine cycling a card like Void Beckoner for the nice deathtouch token and being able to bring it back with Back for More.

archetypes.title: Spells
description: Get ready to sling some spells and shut down your opponent. By filling your deck with enough spells you may even be able to turn your Sprite Dragon into a sizeable threat.
In this deck it is important to find the correct balance of threats to spells. There will be many options from Fire Prophecy to Essence Scatter.

archetypes.title: Humans
description: Humans work best in groups (I know, I know, but it's just a game), so you're going to want to go wide on this one. This archetype is well-positioned to take advantage of cards like Sanctuary Lockdown and Bastion of Remembrance.
Dire Tactics was made for this archetype, and to close out a game you might want to use something like Coordinated Charge.

archetypes.title: Menace
description: Aggro! Aggro! Aggro! I mean of course, right? A good curve is most important in this archetype and remember your ABA's (Always be Attacking). You get some evasiveness from the menace found in these colors, which will help you get your damage in. This archetype really shines when it comes to removal with access to Blood Curdle, Mutual Destruction, and Fire Prophecy all at common level.

archetypes.title: Trample
description: In this archetype you get big meaty creatures and as a bonus they should have trample too (see Proud Wildbonder). An aggressive curve is very important here so remember your 2-drop creatures. In these colors you get good removal in the form of Ram Through and Fire Prophecy.

archetypes.title: Flash
description: "No" is what you will say when your opponent asks to cast something. This archetype is your typical counter/removal control deck with a couple major threats: Essence Scatter, Neutralize, Blood Curdle.

This archetype has good support from the flash theme, just in case your opponent doesn't play anything worth countering on their turn. Cunning Nightbonder gives a little incentive to go the flash route.

archetypes.title: Vigilance
description: Play good stuff! Like always, I know, but with large creatures that have access to flying you start to seem like a threat.

You get some good removal with Pacifism and Ram Through at common level so you better pick one up. You should also be able to take advantage of the vigilance theme going on in this archetype with Keensight Mentor and Frondland Felidar.
